page.title: 03Fyfield and Overton Churches
page.content: The registers of both churches, dating from 1682, have entries for both villages until 1732 when separate records were kept. {Fyfield Church}serves Fyfield and Lockeridge. It dates from the 13th century, with major repairs made in 1634. The floor and tower are of stone, the nave roof of oak. It had 3 bells, but one was given to Alton Priors on joining Overton parish. The lychgate was erected in memory of a local jockey who died at Brighton racecourse. Several buildings nearby were demolished about 1930 for road widening. The present church at{West Overton}is the third one. It is built of local sarsen stones, flint, bricks and Bath stone dressings. The tower with 6 bells is reached up a winding staircase.
